Description: BIG BLACKFOOT CHAPTER OF TROUT UNLIMITED IS PROPOSING TO COLLABORATE WITH THE BLM AND OTHER FEDERAL, STATE, AND PRIVATE PARTNERS TO IMPROVE STREAM HABITAT, RIPARIAN CORRIDORS, WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY CONDITIONS IN THE BLACKFOOT RIVER   NEVADA CREEK WATERSHEDS. THE GOAL IS TO IMPROVE AQUATIC HABITATS IMPORTANT TO WESTSLOPE CUTTHROAT TROUT, OTHER NATIVE NON-SALMONIDS AND THE THREATENED BULL TROUT THAT INHABIT THE STREAM BASIN, INCLUDING PROVIDING HIGH QUALITY WATER TO THE BLACKFOOT RIVER, THE LIFELINE OF THE IMMEDIATE REGION THROUGH STRONG PARTNERSHIPS, FOLLOWING A SCIENCE-BASED APPROACH. PROPOSED WORK WILL INCLUDE PROJECTS THAT RESTORE FISH PASSAGE, RIPARIAN FUNCTION, FLOODPLAIN CONNECTION, INSTREAM HABITAT AND WATER QUALITY CONDITIONS WITHIN THE OVERALL BLACKFOOT RIVER AND NEVADA CREEK WATERSHEDS. EXPECTED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE SEVERAL STREAM CROSSING UPGRADES, ROAD DECOMMISSIONING, STREAM, AND RIPARIAN RESTORATION, GRAZING MANAGEMENT, FISH SCREENS AND OTHER LOW-TECH PROJECTS AIMED TO RESTORE FLOODPLAIN CONNECTION. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE NATIVE TROUT POPULATIONS, MACROINVERTEBRATES, AND OTHER SPECIES DEPENDENT ON HEALTHY RIPARIAN AREAS INCLUDING MIGRATORY SONG BIRDS, SANDHILL CRANES, WATERFOWL, GRIZZLY BEARS, AND AMPHIBIANS. BANK STORAGE THROUGH FLOODPLAIN CONNECTION, WATER TEMPERATURE DECREASES, AND THE REJUVENATION OF A HEALTHY, SELF-SUSTAINING, NATIVE RIPARIAN ECOSYSTEM WILL ALL CONTRIBUTE TO CLIMATE RESILIENCY.

LOCAL OBJECTIVES ARE TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE WATERSHEDS ACROSS DOUGLAS AND CHELAN COUNTIES. LOW TECH PROCESS-BASED RESTORATION WILL OCCUR IN UPPER DOUGLAS CREEK WATERSHED BY RECOVERING STREAMS, ENHANCING WATER QUALITY, AND INCREASING RIPARIAN WIDTHS FOR THE BENEFIT OF NATIVE TROUT AND OTHER SPECIES. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS WATERSHED RESTORATION IN DOUGLAS CREEK WATERSHED, INCLUDING RECONTOURING OF DISTURBED VALLEYS, RETURNING BEAVER STRUCTURES TO THE RIPARIAN AREA, AND RE-ESTABLISHING NATIVE RIPARIAN VEGETATION.

THIS PROJECT INTENDS TO DEVELOP A SCIENTIFICALLY DEFENSIBLE ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW FRAMEWORK FOR 6 REACHES OF THE MAINSTEM RIO GRANDE AND RIO CHAMA THROUGH NEW MEXICO TO ELEPHANT BUTTE RESERVOIR BY LEVERAGING RESOURCES AND THE SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPED THROUGH THE BUREAU OF RECLAMATION RIO GRANDE BASIN STUDY. THIS REACH-SCALE FLOW QUANTIFICATION PROCESS LARGELY FOCUSES ON AQUATIC AND AQUATIC-DEPENDENT THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES (T E). NEW MEXICO WILDERNESS ALLIANCE CO-LEADS, WITH AUDUBON SOUTHWEST, THE NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATION (NGO) SECTORAL COMMITTEE OF THE BASIN STUDY, BRINGING TOGETHER AROUND 15 NATIONAL AND REGIONAL NGOS. AS PART OF THE BASIN STUDY TASKS, THE SECTORAL COMMITTEE IS IDENTIFYING AND DEVELOPING COMMUNITY VALUES RELATED TO ECOLOGICAL HEALTH AND RECREATION  ENVIRONMENTAL WATER NEEDS  SIGNPOSTS AND THRESHOLDS TO HELP DETERMINE WHEN CHANGES ARE OCCURRING OR HAVE OCCURRED IN THE SYSTEM  AND IDENTIFYING INDICATOR SPECIES. THIS PROPOSAL INTENDS TO BUILD OFF THE BASIN STUDYS WORK BY FURTHER DEVELOPING ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW HYPOTHESES, VETTING THESE HYPOTHESES THROUGH A PEER-REVIEW WORKSHOP THAT INCLUDES NATIONAL AND REGIONAL EXPERTS IN ENVIRONMENTAL FLOWS AND NEW MEXICO WATERWAYS, AND COMPLETING A SYNTHESIS REPORT THAT PROVIDES JUSTIFICATION FOR THE RECOMMENDED FLOW TARGETS THROUGH DISCUSSION OF EXISTING LITERATURE AND DATA, INCLUDING ANNOTATED REFERENCES.THE PROJECT HAS THE POTENTIAL TO FURTHER MULTIPLE DOI PRIORITIES, INCLUDING MAKING INVESTMENTS TO SUPPORT THE ADMINISTRATIONS GOAL OF CREATING MILLIONS OF FAMILY-SUPPORTING AND UNION JOBS, WORKING TO CONSERVE AT LEAST 30  EACH OF OUR LANDS AND WATERS BY THE YEAR 2030, AND CENTERING EQUITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE . A DEEP UNDERSTANDING OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW NEEDS IN THESE REACHES WILL HELP TO IDENTIFY WHERE INVESTMENTS SHOULD BE MADE TO BETTER PROTECT BIODIVERSITY, IMPROVE ACCESS TO RECREATION, AND ADDRESS THE CHANGING CLIMATE, AS IDENTIFIED IN DOIS TOP 5 LISTED PRIORITIES. IT CAN ALSO POTENTIALLY AID DOI TO LEVERAGE NATURAL CLIMATE SOLUTIONS  AND GIVE COMMUNITIES NEEDED INFORMATION TO BETTER PROTECT THEIR VALUES AND HEALTH OF THEIR WATERSHEDS. BOTH SCIENTIFICALLY JUSTIFIABLE ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW NUMBERS AND THE REPORT SYNTHESIZING EXISTING INFORMATION WILL FILL NEEDED DATA GAPS THAT CAN HELP INFORM FUTURE RMPS AND OTHER MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT ARE A) A REPORT THAT SYNTHESIZES ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW NEEDS, INCLUDING THE NEEDS OF IDENTIFIED INDICATOR SPECIES (I.E. SOUTHWEST WILLOW FLYCATCHER AND RIO GRANDE SILVERY MINNOW) AND B) FLOW TARGETS ASSOCIATED WITH INSTREAM FLOW NEEDS TO BENEFIT HEALTHY RIVERS, HABITAT, AND SUPPORT IMPERILED AND NATIVE SPECIES. THESE PRODUCTS WILL PROVIDE A LONG-NEEDED ENVIRONMENTAL FLOW FRAMEWORK FOR THE RIO GRANDE IN NEW MEXICO WHICH WILL ASSIST WITH MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND TRADE-OFFS, AS WELL AS SHAPE FUTURE POLICY INITIATIVES AND PRIORITIES AND GUIDE FUTURE INVESTMENTS OF FEDERAL PROGRAMS.

SINCE 2000, THE MISSOULA FIELD OFFICE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM) HAS ACQUIRED APPROXIMATELY 40,000 ACRES OF INDUSTRIAL TIMBERLANDS FROM THE NATURE CONSERVANCY IN THE LOWER BLACKFOOT RIVER WATERSHED. MORE LANDS ARE SLATED TO BE PURCHASED IN THE COMING YEARS. THE ACQUISITION OF THESE TNC LANDS BRINGS A SUBSTANTIAL AMOUNT OF AQUATIC RESOURCES INTO MISSOULA FIELD OFFICE MANAGEMENT, AND IT SUPPORTS THE SALISH AND PEND D OREILLE PEOPLE OF THE CONFEDERATED SALISH AND KOOTENAI TRIBES (CSKT) GOAL OF RESTORING THREATENED BULL TROUT AND OTHER NATIVE FISH IN THEIR HISTORIC TERRITORIES. THE NEWLY ACQUIRED LANDS INCLUDE OCCUPIED BULL TROUT STREAM MILES AND BULL TROUT DESIGNATED CRITICAL HABITAT, AS WELL AS MORE MILES OF WESTSLOPE CUTTHROAT TROUT OCCUPIED STREAMS AND HABITAT. TWO FACTORS PLACE NATIVE FISH, NAMELY BULL TROUT AND WESTSLOPE CUTTHROAT TROUT, AT HIGH-RISK IN THE PROJECT AREA: 1) THE LACK OF LARGE IN-STREAM WOODY DEBRIS AND LARGE LIVE STREAMSIDE TREES AVAILABLE FOR WOODY DEBRIS RECRUITMENT, AND 2) HIGH ROAD DENSITIES THAT CHRONICALLY DELIVER SEDIMENT AND BLOCK FISH PASSAGE. TO RESTORE FISH POPULATIONS TO HISTORICAL LEVELS WILL REQUIRE ADDING WOOD TO STREAMS, AND REDUCING ROAD DENSITIES. THE GOAL OF THIS PARTNERSHIP PROJECT IS TO COOPERATE WITH THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT IN DEVELOPING ON-THE-GROUND RESTORATION PROJECTS TO ADDRESS THE LACK OF IN-STREAM WOOD AND STREAM SEDIMENTATION AND OTHER IMPACTS FROM ROADS. WE WILL INCREASE WATERSHED RESILIENCY AND RESTORE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES IN ACCORDANCE WITH BLM MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES WHILE EXPANDING PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT.

THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PARTNERSHIP WOULD BE TO WORK TOGETHER TO BETTER FACILITATE COLLABORATIVE AQUATIC RESTORATION PROJECTS IN THE ROCK CREEK AND CANTON CREEK WATERSHEDS. THE WORK WOULD FOCUS ON DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF INSTREAM RESTORATION PROJECTS THAT INCREASE HABITAT COMPLEXITY AND RESILIENCY, ACCUMULATE WOOD AND SUBSTRATE INPUTS AND RECONNECT FLOODPLAINS TO HELP RESTORE NATURAL WATERSHED PROCESSES.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00172FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:  THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS CLEARLY DEFINED IN THE PROPOSAL TO AID THE BLM AND OTHER PARTNERS IN THE MANAGEMENT OF JUPITER INLET LIGHTHOUSE OUTSTANDING NATURAL AREA (ONA) TO PROTECT, CONSERVE, AND ENHANCE THE UNIQUE AND NATIONALLY IMPORTANT HISTORICAL, NATURAL, CULTURAL, SCIENTIFIC, EDUCATIONAL, SCENIC, AND RECREATIONAL VALUES OF THE SITE AS STATED IN THE CONGRESSIONAL DESIGNATING LEGISLATION (PUBLIC LAW 110-229 SEC. 202. MAY 8, 2008). THE PROPOSAL FURTHER OUTLINES THE CROSS OVER BETWEEN THE ORGANIZATIONS MISSION AND THE BLMS MANAGEMENT AT THE ONA. THE PROPOSAL IS RELEVANT AS IT AIDS IN ACHIEVING THE DIRECTION SET BY CONGRESS IN THE ONAS DESIGNATION, MEETS WITH BLMS MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVES AND PLANNING FOR THE SITE AND ALIGNS WITH DOI PRIORITIES RELATING TO EXPANDING ACCESS, RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES, AND THE STEWARDSHIP OF PUBLIC LANDS RESOURCES. THE WORK IS REALISTIC BASED ON THE EXPERIENCE BETWEEN THE PROPONENT AND THE BLM AND IS MEASURABLE BASED ON THE ACCOMPLISHMENTS OF THE SPECIFIC PROJECTS WITHIN THE PROPOSAL AND THE OVERALL CONTRIBUTIONS TO MANAGEMENT OF THE ONA E.G., EDUCATIONAL ENHANCEMENT, VISITOR SATISFACTION, SCIENTIFIC EXPLORATION ETC.  THE TECHNICAL APPROACH CLEARLY IDENTIFIES THE METHODS TO ACHIEVE THE OBJECTIVES AND PRESENT A SERIES OF IMPLEMENTABLE PROJECTS SCHEDULED OUT OVER THE COURSE OF THE AGREEMENT. THE SUCCESS OF EACH OF THESE PROJECTS PROVIDES A MEANINGFUL APPROACH TO MEASURE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE WORK. THE PROPOSAL PROVIDES DETAILS OF THE TECHNICAL APPROACH AND OUTCOMES FOR EACH OF THE PROJECTS AND IDENTIFIES THE ROLES THE APPLICANT HAS IN ACHIEVING THEM. THE PROPOSAL INCLUDES A CLEAR SCHEDULE OF MILESTONES TASKS FOR THE DURATION OF THE AGREEMENT. GOALS   ESTIMATED TIMELINES: A)ENGAGE THE LOCAL COMMUNITY, SPECIFICALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS, TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE CRITICAL HABITATS AT THE ONA AND THEIR BENEFITS.  1)PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR VOLUNTEERS TO COLLECT SEEDS FROM HEALTHY, ESTABLISHED PLANTS AT THE ONA WHILE LEARNING MORE ABOUT THE SPECIFIC HABIT, NEEDS OF THE PLANTS AND HOW THEY SUPPORT WILDLIFE.  2)REGULAR ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMMING FOR TARGETED AUDIENCES AND THE PUBLIC.  3)PROVIDE SIGNAGE, SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS, WEBSITES AND EMAIL THAT ENCOURAGE RESPONSIBLE USE OF THE TRAILS. B)ASSIST BLM IN MONITORING NATURAL RESOURCES AT THE ONA. 1)PROVIDE BROAD CITIZEN SCIENCE PROGRAMS AND EVENTS. 2)RECRUIT WEEKLY AND MONTHLY VOLUNTEERS TO PROVIDE CONTINUAL MONITORING OF RESOURCES. MEASURES: A)SCHEDULE 3 NATIVE PLANT MATERIAL VOLUNTEER COLLECTION EVENTS ANNUALLY TO SUPPORT THE BLMS EXISTING PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NATIVE PLANT SOCIETY TO GROW OUT NATIVE PLANTS IN SUPPORT OF PUBLIC LANDS RESTORATION EFFORTS. B)DEVELOP, DESIGN, AND INSTALL INTERPRETIVE SIGNAGE FOR EACH OF THE ONAS FOUR HABITAT AREAS (MINIMUM OF 4 SIGNS) THAT INCORPORATE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS PERTINENT TO THE HABITAT, LEAVE NO TRACE MESSAGING AND MEET THE BLMS DESIGN STANDARDS. C)SUPPORT BLMS SOCIAL MEDIA AND ONLINE PRESENCE THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF CONTENT FOR SHARING ON SOCIAL MEDIA ON BOTH BLM AND LRD CHANNELS. D)DEVELOP A CITIZEN SCIENCE PROGRAM FOR WATER QUALITY TESTING AROUND THE ONA, THAT COULD BE EXPANDED TO MANGROVE AND SEAGRASS MONITORING. E)ENSURE PARTICIPATE IN THE INDIAN RIVER LAGOONS DAY IN THE LIFE MONITORING PROGRAM FROM SITES WITHIN THE ONA ANNUALLY AND UTILIZE THE SAME RIGOROUS INVESTIGATION FOR ROUTINE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS. F) CONDUCT ONE OR MORE EVENTS ANNUAL FOR LATINO CONSERVATION WEEK AT THE ONA.

CONDUCT THE YELLOW CREEK INSTREAM AND MONITORING PROJECT TO IMPROVE THE SALMONID SPAWNING HABITAT IN THIS TRIBUTARY OF THE MAINSTEM OF THE UMPQUA RIVER. THE PROJECT INVOLVES THE PLACEMENT OF INSTREAM LARGE WOOD AND BOULDERS, THE REMOVAL OF INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES IN RIPARIAN AREAS, PLANTING OF NATIVE PLANT SPECIES IN RIPARIAN AREAS, AND EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING OF THE RESTORATION PROJECTS. THESE ACTIONS WILL INCREASE HABITAT COMPLEXITY AND RESILIENCY, ACCUMULATE WOOD AND SUBSTRATE INPUTS AND RECONNECT FLOODPLAINS TO HELP MITIGATE INCREASED STREAM FLOWS.

COOS WATERSHED ASSOCIATION MISSION IS TO SUPPORT ENVIRONMENTAL INTEGRITY AND ECONOMIC STABILITY WITHIN THE COOS WATERSHED BY INCREASING COMMUNITY CAPACITY TO DEVELOP, TEST, PROMOTE, AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN THE INTERESTS OF WATERSHED HEALTH.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00161FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:  US BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT ADMINISTERED FEDERAL LANDS IN MONTANA, WYOMING, UTAH, AND COLORADO HAVE A HIGH DENSITY OF ROAD STREAM CROSSINGS RELATED TO HUMAN ACTIVITIES SUCH AS PETROLEUM PRODUCTION AND GRAZING LEASES. WHERE THESE ROADS INTERSECT WITH STREAMS THERE IS POTENTIAL FOR STREAM FRAGMENTATION AND THE USE OF CULVERTS AND FORDS IS COMMON. DIVERSIONS AND SMALL DAMS ARE ALSO COMMON FEATURES OF THE RIVER NETWORKS ON BLM ADMINISTERED LANDS. ADDRESSING STREAM CONNECTIVITY IN US BLM LANDS IN MONTANA AND WYOMING HAS THE POTENTIAL TO INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF STREAM FISHES TO HUMAN DISTURBANCE AND TO PROLONGED PERIODS OF DROUGHT AND INCREASED VARIABILITY IN STREAM FLOWS THAT ARE EXPECTED WITH CLIMATE CHANGE.  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF POTENTIAL BARRIERS, INCLUDING SMALL DAMS, ROAD CROSSINGS, AND DIVERSIONS, THAT HAVE BEEN ASSESSED FOR AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO 1. SELECT PRIORITY WATERSHEDS AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL BARRIERS TO AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE ON BLM AND ADJACENT LANDS, 2. ASSESS 1300 POTENTIAL BARRIERS BY SURVEYING DAMS, BRIDGES, FORDS, AND DIVERSIONS ON BLM AND ADJACENT LANDS USING THE STANDARDIZED SARP WESTERN AQUATIC ORGANISM PASSAGE SURVEY PROTOCOL, 3. CONTRIBUTE SURVEY ASSESSMENTS TO THE SARP ONLINE BARRIER DATABASE TO BE USED BY STATE, REGIONAL, AND FEDERAL PARTNERS AND 4. PRIORITIZE AND PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE FISH PASSAGE REMEDIATION PROJECTS ON BLM LANDS.

IDENTIFYING AREAS INVADED BY RUSSIAN OLIVE AND AREAS WITH SUITABLE HABITAT THAT ARE LIKELY TO BE INVADED IS CRITICAL TO MANAGING RIPARIAN HABITATS. THIS EFFORT WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO OPTIMIZE CONTROL EFFORTS THAT WILL PROVIDE THE GREATEST BENEFIT TO FISH, WILDLIFE, AND AQUATIC RESOURCES. EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE TO NEWLY ESTABLISHED TREES IS CRITICAL TO LIMITING THE SPREAD OF RUSSIAN OLIVE AS ESTABLISHED STANDS ARE DIFFICULT AND EXPENSIVE TO CONTROL. CONTROL EFFORTS INFORMED BY THIS PROJECT WILL AID IN THE CONSERVATION OF WILDLIFE THAT RELY ON RIPARIAN CORRIDORS, REDUCE WATER LOSS TO EVAPOTRANSPIRATION, AND SUPPORT NATIVE BIODIVERSITY AND NATURAL AQUATIC ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION.
USING VIRTUAL FENCES AS A CONSERVATION TOOL FOR THREATENED AND ENDANGERED FISH.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00161FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:  THE PROPOSED WORK IS RELEVANT BECAUSE THE EFFECTS OF PERSISTENT DROUGHT AND ARIDIFICATION ON WESTERN LANDSCAPES AND WATER SUPPLIES ARE AN ESSENTIAL CONSIDERATION FOR THE BLMS LAND USE PLANNING PROCESS. ADDITIONALLY, UNPRECEDENTED LEVELS OF FUNDING FROM THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW AND THE INFLATION REDUCTION ACT ARE AVAILABLE TO IMPLEMENT PROACTIVE MEASURES TO IMPROVE THE DROUGHT RESILIENCE OF PUBLIC LANDS, SUCH AS RIVERSCAPE RESTORATION. ECOSYSTEM RESILIENCE IS ESSENTIAL TO BLMS ABILITY TO MANAGE FOR SUSTAINED YIELD. THE BLM MUST CONSIDER CHANGING CLIMATIC CONDITIONS AND THE AVAILABILITY OF WATER FOR PUBLIC LAND USE PURPOSES WHEN AUTHORIZING OR MODIFYING LAND USES AND ASSESSING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF RESTORATION PROJECTS. CLOUD-COMPUTING TOOLS SUCH AS DRIS CLIMATE ENGINE, A FREE WEB APPLICATION POWERED BY GOOGLE EARTH ENGINE, QUICKLY AND EASILY INTEGRATE GOVERNMENT, ACADEMIC, AND PRIVATE SECTOR CLIMATE, SATELLITE, AND PLACE-BASED DATASETS AND ARE NEEDED TO INFORM THESE COMPLEX DECISIONS. THE PROPOSED WORK IS DIVIDED INTO THREE REALISTIC TASKS THAT WILL BENEFIT MULTIPLE BLM PROGRAMS, RESULT IN MEASURABLE PRODUCTS AND OUTCOMES, AND WILL ALLOW WIDESPREAD ADOPTION AND OPERATIONAL USAGE OF CLIMATE ENGINE WITHIN THE BLM.  THE TECHNICAL APPROACHES FOR DEVELOPING TUTORIALS ON THE USE OF CLIMATE ENGINE TO ANSWER COMMON BLM MANAGEMENT QUESTIONS, FOR INTEGRATING REMOTE-SENSING DATASETS, AND IMPROVING THE CLIMATE ENGINE API ARE CLEAR. THE ROLES OF THE BLM AND DRI IN DEVELOPING SPECIFIC DELIVERABLES AND DEFINING TARGET DATES FOR MAJOR MILESTONES WILL BE FURTHER CLARIFIED WHEN THE AGREEMENT IS MODIFIED TO OBLIGATE FUNDING FROM SEVERAL BLM PROGRAMS.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: L23AS00161FUNDING OPPORTUNITY GOALS TEXT:  THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM)S ASSESSMENT, INVENTORY, AND MONITORING (AIM) STRATEGY PROVIDES A FRAMEWORK AND STANDARDIZED APPROACH FOR MEASURING THE CONDITION AND TREND OF NATURAL RESOURCES ON THE NATION S PUBLIC LANDS. HEALTHY, SUSTAINABLE ECOSYSTEMS SUPPORT THE DIVERSE MULTIPLE USES AND BENEFITS OF PUBLIC LANDS. TO FULFILL ITS MULTIPLE-USE MISSION, THE BLM GATHERS INFORMATION TO DETERMINE NATURAL RESOURCE CONDITIONS AND HOW THOSE CONDITIONS CHANGE OVER TIME. QUANTITATIVE DATA AND TOOL PRODUCED THROUGH WITH THE AIM STRATEGY ARE ACTIVELY USED BY THE BLM TO GUIDE AND JUSTIFY LAND USES, POLICY ACTIONS, AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA HAS ASSISTED THE BLM WITH DATA COLLECTION AND UNIQUE ANALYSES FOR MANY YEARS. THEY ARE A CENTER OF EXCELLENCE FOR AQUATIC ASSESSMENT, ANALYSIS, PROTOCOLS, MONITORING TOOL MANAGEMENT AND TRAINING. THEY PROVIDE A SKILL SET LACKING IN THE BLM TO ASSIST WITH CRITICAL SCIENCE AND MANAGEMENT QUESTIONS BY USING NOVEL RESEARCH APPROACHES TO ANALYZE DATA COLLECTED.  FOR EACH OF THE FY22 PROPOSED TASKS, THE UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE BLM NOC AND STATE, DISTRICT, AND FIELD OFFICE-LEVEL BIOLOGISTS TO IMPLEMENT DATA COLLECTION ON BLM LANDS AND TO ANSWER SCIENCE QUESTIONS RELEVANT TO BOTH PARTIES AND THE PUBLIC. THIS APPROACH HAS PROVED SUCCESSFUL NOT ONLY ON PAST PROJECTS WITH UNIVERSITY OF MONTANA, BUT BLM WORKS WITH OTHER PARTNERS IN A SIMILAR APPROACH FOR OTHER RESOURCES, SUCH AS TERRESTRIAL AIM. THE TASKS IN THE PROPOSAL ARE LAID OUT CLEARLY WITH CLEAR OUTCOMES WHICH CAN EASILY BE MONITORED. TIMELINES ARE REASONABLE AND THE APPROACH IS EXTREMELY DETAILED, PROVIDING MORE THAN ENOUGH INFORMATION TO DETERMINE VALIDITY. GOALS AND ESTIMATED TIMELINES 1. ASSESS AND MONITOR AQUATIC RESOURCES THROUGHOUT THE WESTERN UNITED STATES.  CREWS WILL BE HIRED PRIOR TO THE BLM SPONSORED TRAINING. DURING TRAINING, CREWS WILL CALIBRATE WITH OCRMW AND BLM STAFF. IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING TRAINING, AND BEFORE DATA COLLECTION BEGINS, CREWS WILL ALSO CALIBRATE WITH A LOCAL BLM STAFF MEMBER. CREW MANAGERS WILL REGULARLY QA QC DATA AFTER EACH HITCH, AND WILL IMMEDIATELY COMMUNICATE POTENTIAL ISSUES WITH THE CREWS. CREWS AND OCRMW STAFF WILL HAVE A ONE-MONTH CHECK-IN, TYPICALLY AFTER 2 FULL HITCHES, TO DISCUSS POTENTIAL ISSUES, AND GO OVER THE DATA THAT HAS BEEN ALREADY COLLECTED. ALL DIGITAL AND PHYSICAL (I.E., WATER QUALITY AND MACRO INVERTEBRATE) DATA WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE BLM NO LATER THAN OCTOBER 31 OF EACH YEAR.  2. CARRY OUT DATA ANALYSIS TO SUPPORT MULTIPLE LEVELS OF DECISION-MAKING.  THE OCRMW PROJECT MANAGER WILL WORK WITH THE BLM NOC POC QUARTERLY, AT A MINIMUM TO ENSURE THAT DATA ANALYSES ARE MATCHING THE NEEDS OF THE BLM. OCRMW STAFF WILL REGULARLY PRESENT PRELIMINARY AND FINAL ANALYSES AS FORMAL PRESENTATIONS OR INFORMAL WEBINARS AS AVAILABLE.  3. PERSONNEL SUPPORT FOR FIELD METHODS TRAINING.  TRAINERS WILL BE REGULARLY PROVIDED EACH YEAR. THE LIST OF TRAINERS WILL BE PROVIDED TO BLM IN LATE WINTER, DEPENDING ON THE TIMING AND LOCATION OF TRAININGS.

UNDERSTANDING AQUATIC HABITAT AND WATER RESOURCE RESPONSES TO RAPID AND ONGOING CHANGES IN BOTH CLIMATEAND LAND USE HAS PROVIDED GUIDANCE TO SCIENCE AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT IN THE FISH CREEK WATERSHED OBSERVATORY (FCWO). STARTING WITH RIVER GAUGING AND CLIMATE MONITORING IN 2001, AQUATIC HABITAT OBSERVATIONS AND RESEARCH IN AND AROUND THE FISH CREEK WATERSHED HAVE GRADUALLY EXPANDED IN STEP WITH RESOURCE MANAGEMENT NEEDS IN THE NATIONAL PETROLEUM RESERVE IN ALASKA (NPR A). TARGETED LAKE AND STREAM MONITORING AND FISH HABITAT STUDIES IN THE GREATER MOOSE S TOOTH UNIT AND MOST RECENTLY THE WILLOW UNIT ARE PROVIDING SITE SPECIFIC DATA PRIOR TO NEW PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT. MORE BROADLY, WATERSHED SCALE INTERDISCIPLINARY SCIENCE IN THE FCWO MERGES GEOGRAPHIC ANALYSIS AND CLASSIFICATION WITH CLIMATE AND HYDROLOGIC MODELING AND BIOLOGICAL INVENTORIES TO UNDERSTAND POTENTIAL IMPACTS OF LAND USE AND CLIMATE CHANGE AND INFORM ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT AND DECISION MAKING THAT HELPS TO ENSURE THE BLM FULFILLS ITS RESPONSIBILITY TO ENCOURAGE ENVIRONMENTALLY RESPONSIBLE DEVELOPMENT OF ENERGY ON PUBLIC LANDS. DATA AND SCIENTIFIC FINDINGS FROM THE FCWO ARE ADDITIONALLY INTENDED TO SERVE AS A MODEL FOR OTHER LANDS AND WATERS OF THE NPR A AND THE BROADER ARCTIC COASTAL PLAIN OF ALASKA. THE PROPOSED FCWO EFFORTS WILL ADDRESS MULTIPLE PRIORITY WORK NEEDS IDENTIFIED BY THE BLM ALASKA AQUATIC HABITAT MANAGEMENT (AHM) PROGRAM, INCLUDING MONITORING PHYSICAL, CHEMICAL, AND BIOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF AQUATIC HABITATS, EVALUATING THE SUSTAINABILITY OF WATER RESOURCES FOR THE BENEFIT OF FISH AND RIPARIAN HABITATS, AND ENSURING TIMELY PROCESSING OF DATA AND DATA QUALITY. BY ADDRESSING THIS PRIORITY WORK, THE FCWO WILL CONTINUE TO ADVANCE DEPARTMENT OF INTERIOR (DOI) AND ADMINISTRATION PRIORITIES FOCUSED ON CLIMATE CHANGE, ENGAGING RURAL AND INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES, AND PROMOTE DECISION MAKING INFORMED BY THE BEST AVAILABLE SCIENCE AND DATA.

WET MEADOWS IN THE GUNNISON BASIN OF COLORADO ARE A CRITICAL BROOD REARING HABITAT FOR THE GROUND DWELLING BIRD THE GUNNISON SAGE GROUSE  CENTROCERCUS MINIMUS  WHICH IS LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  THE SAGE GROUSE REQUIRE A LARGE CONTIGUOUS AREA OF SAGEBRUSH  ARTEMISIA SPP   FOR COVER YEAR ROUND AND WET MEADOW AND RIPARIAN ECOSYSTEMS WHERE THEY FEED THEIR YOUNG IN THE SUMMER  REGIONS WITHIN SOUTHWESTERN COLORADO HISTORICALLY OCCUPIED BY WET MEADOWS HAVE BEEN SEVERELY DEGRADED BY HUMAN ACTIVITIES RESULTING IN HEAD CUTS, EROSION, LOWERED WATER TABLES, SOIL COMPACTION BY TRAILING FROM LIVESTOCK AND WILDLIFE, DEVELOPMENT OF ROADS, AND ENCROACHMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES  THESE IMPACTS CAN DECREASE THE FOOD SUPPLY OF CHICKS AND POTENTIALLY AFFECT CHICK SURVIVAL  RESTORATION OF THESE WET MEADOWS HAS LED TO AN INCREASE IN PLANT PRODUCTIVITY WHICH IS A PRIMARY SOURCE OF ORGANIC MATTER AND C TO THE SOIL  HOWEVER, LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT WHETHER RESTORATION IN THESE WATERSHEDS HAS LED TO INCREASES IN SOIL MOISTURE AND C STORAGE LIMITING OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THESE ECOSYSTEMS  RESILIENCE TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND THEIR ABILITY TO MITIGATE CLIMATE CHANGE THROUGH SOIL CARBON SEQUESTRATION

THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO IMPROVE THE RIPARIAN AND AQUATIC HABITAT RESILIENCY OF THE LOWER EAGLE RIVER  THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED BY RE ESTABLISHING FLOODPLAIN CONNECTIVITY, IMPROVING IN CHANNEL FISH HABITAT AND ENGAGING THE COMMUNITY IN UNDERSTANDING THE IMPORTANCE OF WATERSHED RESTORATION AN EARLY ASSESSMENT OF THE LOWER EAGLE RIVER BY THE PROJECT PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS, INCLUDING THE EAGLE RIVER WATERSHED COUNCIL, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM , COLORADO PARKS AND  WILDLIFE  CPW  AND A WATER ENGINEER, IDENTIFIED THE PROJECT LOCATION AND ITS CONTRIBUTIONS TO WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY ISSUES AND LACK OF PROPER WILDLIFE HABITAT  THROUGHOUT MOST OF THE PROJECT REACH, WHICH LIES FROM THE EASTERN BLM PROPERTY BOUNDARY NEAR THE GYPSUM CAMPGROUND TO THE BLM PROPERTY BOUNDARY DOWNSTREAM, THE FLOODPLAIN HAS BECOME DISCONNECTED FROM THE RIVER  THE PROJECT S OBJECTIVES, TO RECONNECT THE FLOODPLAIN AND IMPROVE INCHANNEL HABITAT, WILL PROVIDE HABITAT FOR NATIVE WILDLIFE AND FISH SPECIES TO THRIVE, WILL IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY AND CAN HELP MITIGATE THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ACTIVELY MAINTAIN A WATERSHED WIDE STAKEHOLDER PARTNERSHIP AIMED AT THE ASSESSMENT, IMPROVEMENT, RESTORATION, AND PROTECTION OF THE UPPER ARKANSAS WATERSHED FOR PRESENT AND FUTURE GENERATIONS  WE ARE COMMITTED TO LONG TERM STRATEGIES, NOVEL RESTORATION APPROACHES, AND ONGOING LAND MANAGEMENT TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH AND FUNCTION OF THIS WATERSHED WE WORK WITH LOCAL EXPERTS TO PERFORM SITE SPECIFIC WATERSHED HEALTH ASSESSMENTS  THESE ASSESSMENTS IDENTIFY KEY RIPARIAN CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES  OUR FOCUS ON RIPARIAN RESTORATION INCREASES THE ABILITY OF OUR STREAMS TO FILTER UPLAND EROSION IMPROVING WATER QUALITY  ALONG WITH HOLISTIC RANGE MANAGEMENT, AND SELECTIVE SPOT TREATMENT OF UPLAND EROSION CONTROL WE ARE WORKING TO IMPROVE THIS WATERSHED S HEALTH THROUGH DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS HIGHLIGHTING BEST PRACTICES IN HOLISTIC RANGE MANAGEMENT, EROSION CONTROL, AND RIPARIAN RESTORATION WE WILL SHOWCASE EFFECTIVE LAND STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES THAT WILL SERVE AS A MODEL FOR THE WATERSHED

IN THIS PROJECT, BLM AND MOUNTAIN STUDIES INSTITUTE  MSI , WILL IMPLEMENT INNOVATION PARTNERSHIP FOR ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION AND NATURE BASED SOLUTIONS  PARTNERSHIP  PROJECT, DESIGNED TO ENGAGE IN THE IDENTIFICATION OF RESTORATION PRIORITIES AND DEVELOP DECISION AND COLLABORATION TOOLS TO ADVANCE THE PACE AND SCALE OF RESTORING BLM S LANDS IN THE ANIMAS WATERSHED  ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION CAN BE DEFINED AS  THE PROCESS OF ASSISTING THE RECOVERY OF AN ECOSYSTEM THAT HAS BEEN DEGRADED, DAMAGED OR DESTROYED  THROUGH ACTIVITIES THAT ENABLE NATURAL PROCESSES TO RETURN THE FORM AND FUNCTION OF A LANDSCAPE OR LOCATION  SOCIETY OF ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION, 2004   MSI WILL TEAM WITH SPECIALISTS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL EXPERTISE FOR PLANNING, MAPPING, ASSESSMENT, AND IMPLEMENTATION TO ASSIST THE BLM RESTORATION AND RECLAMATION GOALS ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION OF HEADWATERS OF THE ANIMAS RIVER, UNCOMPAHGRE RIVER, AND SAN JUAN RIVER, WHICH ARE ALL TRIBUTARIES OF THE COLORADO RIVER  THIS PROJECT IS LOCATED IN THE TRIBUTARIES OF THE SAN JUAN AND COLORADO WATERSHEDS, AND INCLUDE THE BLM ALPINE LOOP SCENIC BACKCOUNTRY BYWAY, BLM ALPINE TRIANGLE RECREATION AREA, AND BONITA PEAK MINING DISTRICT SUPERFUND SITE
CO AQUATIC RESOURCES CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION PROJECTS

OUR PROPOSED WORK WILL SUPPORT MULTIPLE GOALS OF THE ALASKA BLM AQUATIC HABITAT MANAGEMENT AND FISHERIES PROGRAM AND DOI PRIORITIES WITH RESPECT TO ENSURING RESPONSIBLE DEVELOPMENT ON PUBLIC LANDS AND WATERS AND MONITORING SUBSISTENCE AND RECREATIONAL FISHERIES  CONTAMINANT LOADS IN NORTHERN ALASKA FRESHWATER FISHES HAVE NOT BEEN WELL DOCUMENTED PREVIOUSLY, WITH ONLY LIMITED SAMPLES COLLECTED FROM A SMALL NUMBER OF SPECIES AT FEW LOCATIONS  MANY NORTHERN ALASKA FISHES BIOACCUMULATE CONTAMINANTS AT CONCENTRATIONS HIGH ENOUGH TO BE OF CONCERN FOR HUMAN CONSUMPTION  MULTIPLE BOREAL AND ARCTIC FISHES ARE HEAVILY UTILIZED AS SUBSISTENCE FOOD SOURCES BY ALASKA NATIVE PEOPLES AND OTHER RURAL RESIDENTS  CONSEQUENTLY, HEALTHY FISH POPULATIONS ARE CRITICAL TO RURAL FOOD SECURITY IN ALASKA  IN ADDITION, SIGNIFICANT SPORT FISHING EFFORT AND HARVEST OCCURS ALONG ALASKA S NORTHERN ROAD SYSTEM  THUS, THE CONTAMINANT LOADS IN THESE FISHES, AND THE POSSIBLE HEALTH EFFECTS ON SUBSISTENCE AND SPORT FISHERS THAT CONSUME THEM, NEED TO BE ASSESSED FURTHER OUR OBJECTIVES BUILD FROM PRIOR WORK WE HAVE DONE IN NORTHERN ALASKA  WE WILL  1  CONDUCT A SURVEY OF HEAVY METALS CONTAMINATION IN THE TISSUES OF IMPORTANT SUBSISTENCE AND SPORT FISH SPECIES WITHIN OR ADJACENT TO NORTHERN ALASKA BLM LANDS TO PROVIDE BASELINE DATA IN ADVANCE OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND DEVELOPMENT, AND 2  TO ASSESS HUMAN HEALTH IMPLICATIONS OF CURRENT FISH CONTAMINANT LOADS IN THESE WATERS

THE WESTERN ASSOCIATION OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES  WAFWA  IN ASSOCIATION WITH ITS WESTERN NATIVE TROUT INITIATIVE  WNTI  SEEKS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE THROUGH THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT FOR ASSESSMENT, PROJECTS DATABASE, AND COMMUNICATIONS SUPPORT TO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE THE STATE FISH AND WILDLIFE AGENCIES, FEDERAL AGENCIES, LOCAL AND REGIONAL GOVERNMENTS AND OTHER ENTITIES, OTHER STAKEHOLDERS AND THE PUBLIC AT LARGE OPPORTUNITIES FOR COLLABORATION, INCREASED AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF NATIVE TROUT HABITAT CONSERVATION, AND TO SUCCESSFULLY IMPLEMENT PRIORITY ACTIONS FOR THE CONSERVATION  PROTECTION, RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT  OF HABITAT FOR 21 FOCAL SPECIES ACROSS 12 WESTERN U S  STATES AS A NATIONALLY RECOGNIZED FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP, WNTI PROVIDES A VARIETY OF COORDINATION AND FACILITATION SERVICES TO OUR PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS AS WELL AS OTHER NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGERS AND INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS THROUGHOUT 12 WESTERN U S  STATES  EFFORTS SINCE 2006 HAVE LED TO FOSTERING RELATIONSHIPS THAT PROVIDE A GREATER LEVEL OF INFORMATION SHARING AND IMPROVED COLLABORATION WITHIN THE REGION  THIS AGREEMENT WILL ENABLE WNTI TO IMPLEMENT ELEMENTS OF THE WNTI STRATEGIC PLAN AND THE NATIONAL FISH HABITAT ACTION PLAN IN 12 WESTERN U S  STATES  WNTI SEEKS TO ADVANCE THE EFFORTS OF STATE, FEDERAL, AND PRIVATE PARTNERS WHO SHARE A VISION OF CONSERVING AND PROTECTING AQUATIC HABITATS IN RIVERS, STREAMS, LAKES, AND RESERVOIRS THROUGHOUT THE WESTERN UNITED STATES WNTI IS A PROGRAM UNDER WAFWA, AND WAFWA PROVIDES THE FISCAL SPONSORSHIP TO THE PARTNERSHIP  CONTINUING TO FOCUS ON THE DELIVERY OF HIGH QUALITY PROJECTS AS WELL AS PROVIDING SCIENCE AND DATA EXPERTISE AND SUPPORT IS THE BASIS FOR THIS FUNDING REQUEST  SPECIFICALLY, THIS AGREEMENT WILL PROVIDE FUNDING FOR UPDATING 12 SPECIES STATUS REPORTS AND INCORPORATING OTHER ASSESSMENT TOOLS INTO OUR EXISTING WEBSITE AND STRATEGIC DOCUMENTATION  ANALYSIS AND UPGRADE OF A PROJECTS DATABASE FOR BETTER FUNCTIONALITY AND SPECIES, PUBLIC, AND STAKEHOLDER BENEFIT  UPDATING OF SPECIES, LOCATION, AND RECREATIONAL ACCESS INFORMATION FOR BLM PUBLIC LANDS INCLUDED IN THE WESTERN NATIVE TROUT CHALLENGE  TECHNICAL EXPERTISE AND SUPPORT IN ASSISTING IN THE REVIEW AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE 2025 NATIONAL FISH HABITAT PARTNERSHIP  NFHP  NATIONAL ASSESSMENT  AND DEVELOPMENT OF OTHER ASSESSMENT PRODUCTS TO FILL DATA GAPS, AS REQUIRED BY THE AMERICA S CONSERVATION ENHANCEMENT ACT  ACE ACT  LEGISLATION

THIS PROJECT PROPOSAL BY THE NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF WETLAND MANAGERS  NAWM  IS DESIGNED TO  ENCOURAGE THE ADOPTION OF BEAVER RELATED RESTORATION  BRR  BEST PRACTICES TO FOSTER CLIMATE ADAPTIVE  HABITAT MANAGEMENT IN THE U S  BRR APPROACHES ARE DESIGNED TO MINIMIZE THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE,  INCL  REDUCING THE IMPACTS OF DROUGHT, FLOODING, AND WILDFIRES AS WELL AS BUFFERING AGAINST EXTREME HEAT  EVENTS AND SEQUESTERING CARBON  BEAVER MIMICRY APPROACHES INCLUDE BEAVER DAM ANALOGUES  BDA  AND  POST ASSISTED LOG STRUCTURES  PALS   BRR PRACTICES ALSO INCLUDE VEGETATION RESTORATION ALONG STREAMS TO  ATTRACT BEAVERS WITHOUT RELOCATION BY HUMANS  THIS PROJECT WILL LINK RESTORATION PRACTITIONERS, BRR EXPERTS,  RESEARCHERS, POLICY MAKERS, AND LANDOWNERS TO DISCUSS CLIMATE IMPLICATIONS, PLACEMENT OF BRR TO ADDRESS  CHANGING CLIMATE PRESSURES, AND LESSONS LEARNED THAT CAN INFORM AND IMPROVE NEW PROJECTS  AND TO  ENCOURAGE THE USE OF LOW COST, NATURE BASED BRR APPROACHES  THROUGH THE LENS OF CLIMATE ADAPTATION, THIS  PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON IMPROVING THE USE AND QUALITY OF BRR AS A RESTORATION TOOL TO INCREASE THE RESILIENCY  AND ADAPTABILITY OF AT RISK AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS TO THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE  THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP AND DELIVER  1  A NATIONAL PROJECT WORKGROUP THAT MEETS MONTHLY TO GUIDE THE  WORK OF THE PARTNERS THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT, INCL  A STRONG FOCUS ON REPRESENTATION FROM TRIBAL  COMMUNITIES  2  DEVELOPMENT OF A PRACTITIONER GUIDE ON VETTED, EFFECTIVE BRR BEST PRACTICES PRESENTED BY  REGION AND CLIMATE CONDITION, INCL  COMMUNICATION SUCCESS STORIES AROUND BRR TECHNIQUES  3  RESEARCH  AND REVIEW LEADING TO A WHITE PAPER ON POLICY, LEGAL, AND REGULATORY CONSIDERATIONS FOR BRR PLANNERS AND  PRACTITIONERS  4  PLANNING AND DELIVERY OF 2 REGIONAL WORKSHOPS DELIVERED IN CONJUNCTION WITH EXISTING  BRR CONFERENCES TO TRAIN PRACTITIONERS IN CLIMATE ADAPTATION FOCUSED BRR NEEDS, TECHNIQUES,  CONSIDERATIONS, TOOLS, AND RESOURCES, AS WELL AS COMMUNICATIONS TRAINING FOR WORK WITH TARGET AUDIENCES   4  4 BRR WEBINARS FOCUSED ON CLIMATE RELATED CONSIDERATIONS FOR USE OF BRR BEST PRACTICES TO ADDRESS  FLOODING, DROUGHT, AND WILDFIRES, INCL  TARGETED PRACTICES, CASE STUDIES, AND LESSONS LEARNED  5  10 12 ANYTIME, ANYWHERE ACCESS CLIMATE ADAPTATION FOCUSED BRR ONLINE TRAINING MODULES WITH LEARNING  OBJECTIVES, VIDEO TRAINING PRESENTATIONS, KNOWLEDGE BASED QUIZZES, AND OPTIONAL CERTIFICATES OF  PAGE 2 COMPLETION  AND 6  OUTREACH TO TARGETED COMMUNITIES ON CLIMATE FOCUSED BRR APPROACHES, PROCESSES, AND  RESOURCES FOR THEIR CONSIDERATION IN RESTORATION PLANNING  AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, WITHIN THE GRANT PROJECT PERIOD  1  RESTORATION PLANNERS AND PRACTITIONERS WILL  HAVE INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF EFFECTIVE BRR PRACTICES AND THEIR VALUE AS CLIMATE RESILIENCY TOOLS AND IMPROVED COMMUNICATION BETWEEN PRACTITIONERS, PLANNERS, AND DECISION MAKERS AROUND THE USE OF BRR AS  A CLIMATE ADAPTATION TOOL  2  AQUATIC HABITAT RESTORATION DECISION MAKING AND PLANNING  ESP  BY TRIBES  WILL  INCREASE CONSIDERATION AND INCORPORATION OF APPROPRIATE BRR APPROACHES  3  TRIBAL, STATE, FEDERAL, LOCAL  AGENCY, NONPROFIT, AND ACADEMIC RESTORATION PRACTITIONERS WILL INCREASE COLLABORATION AND SHARING OF BRRFOCUSED EXPERTISE, FINANCIAL AND SKILL BASED RESOURCES  4  THERE WILL BE AN OVERALL INCREASE IN THE CAPACITY  AND EXPERTISE TO DEVELOP BRR PROJECTS AS CLIMATE ADAPTATION TOOLS ACROSS THE U S  5  AN INCREASED NUMBER  OF RESTORATION PRACTITIONERS  ESP  THOSE WORKING ON TRIBAL RESTORATION PROJECTS  WILL BE SKILLED IN THE USE OF  BRR TOOLS  FOLLOWING THE GRANT PERIOD, AN INCREASED NUMBER OF PERMIT AND FUNDING APPLICATIONS SEEKING  TO IMPLEMENT BRR IN ON THE GROUND RESTORATION PROJECTS WILL BE SUBMITTED AND FUNDED  OVER TIME, THE  PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO RESULT IN AN INCREASE IN THE CLIMATE RESILIENCY OF RESTORED HABITAT IN AREAS WHERE BRR  RESTORATIONS WERE COMPLETED AND ASSOCIATED BENEFITS TO THOSE ECOSYSTEMS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD TO ENABLE THE OREGON   NATURAL DESERT ASSOCIATION TO ASSIST THE BLM WITH THE PASSIVE AND ACTIVE   RIPARIAN RESTORATION PROJECTS WHICH ACHIEVE BLM LAND USE PLAN OBJECTIVES FOR   RIPARIAN AND OTHER MESIC HABITAT RESOURCES IN THE PRINEVILLE DISTRICT    ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE VOLUNTEER RESTORATION PROJECTS THAT INVOLVE THE   BUILDING AND REPAIR OF RIPARIAN EXCLOSURE FENCES, PLANTING OF NATIVE SPECIES   AND CONSTRUCTION OF PERMITTED IN STREAM STRUCTURES SUCH AS BEAVER DAM   ANALOGUES AND LOG JAMS  DELIVERABLES OF THIS PARTNERSHIP INCLUDE SUCCESSFULLY   IMPLEMENTING THREE PROJECTS, ENGAGING 30 VOLUNTEERS, AND INVENTORYING AND   REPORTING ON POTENTIAL FUTURE RIPARIAN RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES IN THE   PRINEVILLE DISTRICT

THE MONTANA CLIMATE OFFICE  MCO  WILL UTILIZE THEIR PROGRAMMING SKILLS, REMOTE SENSING SKILLS, AND EXPERTISE IN CLIMATE SCIENCE TO CO PRODUCE THE TOOLS, WORKFLOWS, AND TRAINING MODULES THAT THE TYPICAL INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAM NEEDS TO INFORM ROUTINE NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT QUESTIONS  GIVEN THE VARIABLE EFFECTS OF WEATHER AND CLIMATE ON THE RESOURCES AND USES THAT THE BLM ADMINISTERS, IT IS INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT TO ACCOUNT FOR THOSE IMPACTS WHEN PLANNING AND DESIGNING MANAGEMENT DECISIONS  DESPITE THE ABUNDANCE OF SATELLITE AND FIELD DATA THAT CAN PROVIDE MUCH OF THIS INFORMATION, THEY ARE CURRENTLY STORED IN DISPARATE DATABASES AND FORMATS  CONSEQUENTLY, THE WORKFLOWS THAT ONE MUST FOLLOW TO ANALYZE THE DATA ARE TOO TIME CONSUMING AND TECHNICALLY COMPLEX FOR THE TYPICAL ID TEAM MEMBER  HYDROLOGISTS, BIOLOGISTS, SOIL SCIENTISTS, RANGE CONS, ETC    THESE HIGH RESOLUTION, NEAR REAL TIME DATASETS ARE THEREFORE INFREQUENTLY USED TO INFORM ROUTINE MANAGEMENT QUESTIONS  INSTEAD, THEY ARE LARGELY STUCK IN THE DOMAIN OF ACADEMIA, FOR USE IN RETROSPECTIVE STUDIES AND PRIMARY LITERATURE  THIS PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY ADDRESS THESE DATA MANAGEMENT AND ANALYSIS BOTTLENECKS, THEREBY ENABLING MORE BLM STAFF TO USE THESE DATA TO INFORM A BROAD ARRAY OF COMMON MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, WHEN, WHERE, AND AT THE SPATIAL SCALE THAT IS RELEVANT TO THE QUESTION AND ASSOCIATED MANAGEMENT DECISION  SPECIFICALLY, THE MCO WILL   I  CONSOLIDATE AND PRE FORMAT DISPARATE FIELD AND SATELLITE DERIVED CLIMATE, SOIL, AND VEGETATION DATASETS INTO A CENTRAL DATABASE   II  COORDINATE WITH THE BLM AND PARTNERS TO IDENTIFY THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE AND WEATHER ON THEIR RESOURCES AND ADMINISTERED USES,  III  DEVELOP SIMPLE PLOTTING, VISUALIZATION, AND ANALYSIS TOOLS THAT INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAMS CAN USE TO DEVELOP MANAGEMENT DECISIONS THAT ACCOUNT FOR THE INFLUENCE OF WEATHER CLIMATE ON THE RESOURCES AND USES THEY ADMINISTER, AND  IV  TEACH INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAMS HOW TO USE THE TOOLS AND ASSOCIATED WORKFLOWS TO ANSWER THOSE QUESTIONS MORE EFFICIENTLY AND EFFECTIVELY  FOR A MORE IN DEPTH SUMMARY OF THE GOALS, OBJECTIVES, AND RELATED TASKS THAT WILL BE COMPLETED VIA THIS AGREEMENT, SEE THE TABLE OF MILESTONES IN THE APPLICANT S PROJECT PROPOSAL

A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT TO SUPPORT THE BLM S AQUATIC RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM  THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE THE BLM WITH THE TOOLS NEEDED TO  1  ASSESS THE ECOLOGICAL  BIOLOGICAL, PHYSICAL, AND CHEMICAL  STATUS OF THE AQUATIC RESOURCES MANAGED BY THE BLM, 2  IDENTIFY THE PRIMARY LAND USE ACTIVITIES AND STRESSORS RESPONSIBLE FOR EXISTING WATER RESOURCE IMPAIRMENTS, AND 3  TARGET MANAGEMENT ACTIONS THAT WILL MOST EFFECTIVELY RESTORE IMPAIRED AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS TO DESIRED CONDITIONS  WE WILL ADDRESS THESE GOALS BY PURSUING 12 OBJECTIVES THAT BUILD ON PREVIOUS WORK WE AND OTHERS HAVE CONDUCTED IN COLLABORATION WITH THE BLM AND OTHER FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES THE PRIMARY OUTCOMES OF THIS WORK WILL BE  1  THE PRODUCTION OF SCIENTIFICALLY SOUND AND INTERPRETABLE TOOLS TO ASSESS ECOLOGICAL STATUS AND TRENDS OF AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS, 2  THE PRODUCTION OF SCIENTIFICALLY SOUND TOOLS FOR ASSESSING THE CAUSES OF ECOLOGICAL IMPAIRMENT  INCLUDING THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE , 3  ASSISTANCE IN PREPARING EFFICIENT AND EASILY INTERPRETABLE REPORTS FOR PUBLIC CONSUMPTION, AND 4  ASSISTANCE IN TRAINING OF CURRENT AND FUTURE BLM STAFF TO MAINTAIN A HIGHLY SKILLED WORKFORCE  THE PRODUCTS WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT LOCAL BLM STAFF BY PROVIDING THE TYPE OF INFORMATION NEEDED TO GUIDE PROJECT MANAGEMENT, NATIONAL LEVEL BLM STAFF RESPONSIBLE FOR DEVELOPING BROAD SCALE POLICIES REGARDING WATERSHED AND WATERBODY PROTECTION AND RESTORATION, AND THE PUBLIC WHO DEMAND SOUND ESTIMATES OF THE CONDITION OF PUBLIC LANDS AND WATERS  THESE PRODUCTS WILL ALSO BENEFIT STATE WATER QUALITY MONITORING AND ASSESSMENT PROGRAMS THAT OFTEN PARTNER WITH BLM AND OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES IN PRODUCING STATEWIDE, BIENNIAL INTEGRATED WATER QUALITY ASSESSMENTS TO CONGRESS

TROUT UNLIMITED  TU  WILL BUILD AWARENESS AND SUPPORT OF FISH HABITAT RECLAMATION AND RESTORATION EFFORTS THROUGH COLLABORATION, EDUCATION, AND COMMUNICATION STRATEGIES  TU WILL WORK WITH THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM  TO PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE ONGOING RECLAMATION PROJECT ON NOME CREEK, IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE FUTURE PROJECTS, AND BUILD PARTNERSHIPS TO SUPPORT AND HELP IMPLEMENT FUTURE PROJECTS  THIS COLLABORATION WILL INFORM TU S STORYTELLING PROJECTS TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ON THE VALUE OF AND NEED FOR THIS WORK  COMMUNICATION EFFORTS WILL INCLUDE DIGITAL ENGAGEMENT TACTICS, EARNED AND PAID MEDIA, THE PRODUCTION OF EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND VIDEO, AS WELL AS COMMUNITY EVENTS  THE PROGRAM WILL FACILITATE A WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOP TO TRAIN LABORERS IN RECLAMATION AND RESTORATION PRACTICES  THIS WILL GROW THE LOCAL LABOR POOL AVAILABLE TO SUPPORT RECLAMATION AND RESTORATION AND HELP EDUCATE PLACER MINERS ON WATERSHED RESTORATION TECHNIQUES  FUNDING WILL SUPPORT TU STAFF SALARY, EDUCATION MATERIALS, DIGITAL STORYTELLING PRODUCTS, AND WORKSHOP EXPENSES THE PROGRAM WILL DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE BY TRAINING AND EDUCATING ALASKANS THROUGH THE WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOP  THE PROGRAM WILL ALSO SUPPORT THE GROWTH OF RECLAMATION AND RESTORATION THROUGHOUT ALASKA, CREATING GREATER OPPORTUNITIES FOR ALASKANS TO BE EMPLOYED IN FUTURE PROJECTS THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE DIRECTLY ALIGNED WITH BLM ALASKA AQUATIC HABITAT MANAGEMENT PROGRAM S WORK TO RESTORE AQUATIC RESOURCES AFFECTED BY PAST AND PRESENT IMPACTS  THE PROGRAM S FOCUS ON IDENTIFYING AND BUILDING PARTNERSHIPS WILL HELP BUILD BROAD COMMUNITY SUPPORT AND ENGAGEMENT AND ENHANCE BLM S ABILITY TO SECURE FUTURE FUNDING MATCHES  THIS EFFORT IS ALSO ALIGNED WITH THE PROGRAM S FOCUS ON COLLABORATION WITH PARTNERS AND COMMUNITIES TO FOSTER ADAPTIVE APPROACHES TO RESTORATION  THE WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOP WILL ADVANCE THE PROGRAM S FOCUS ON EDUCATION AND OUTREACH AND BUILDING PUBLIC AND INTERAGENCY SUPPORT FOR RESTORATION, AS WILL TU S COMMUNICATIONS EFFORTS THIS PROJECT WILL HELP ENSURE THE NOME CREEK RECLAMATION EFFORTS ARE COMPLETED WITH INCREASED PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE AND SUPPORT, PRODUCE A SCIENTIFIC ASSESSMENT TO IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE RESTORATION AND RECLAMATION NEEDS IN COLD WATER FISH HABITAT IN ALASKA, DEVELOP PARTNERSHIPS TO SUPPORT FUTURE PROJECTS, ORGANIZE AND FACILITATE A WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOP, AND HELP PROMOTE A PUBLIC THAT IS MORE AWARE AND SUPPORTIVE OF RECLAMATION AND RESTORATION EFFORTS

ACCS PROPOSES TO WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH BLM TO DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK FOR IDENTIFYING PRIORITY SITES OR WATERSHEDS FOR LONG TERM MONITORING OF WATER TEMPERATURES AND WATER QUALITY AND ASSIST IN ESTABLISHING NEW MONITORING SITES IN DIFFERENT REGIONS OF ALASKA  THIS PROJECT WILL FUND THE PLANNING PROCESS TO COORDINATE MEETINGS WITH BLM FIELD OFFICES, GATHER GEOSPATIAL DATASETS TO INFORM THE SELECTION FRAMEWORK  E G , EXISTING MONITORING SITES, THREATS, TOPOGRAPHY, ACCESS, ETC  , AND ASSIST BLM AS NEEDED IN SELECTING PRIORITY SITES AND PARAMETERS FOR MONITORING  FUNDING IS ALSO INCLUDED FOR ACCS STAFF TO HELP ESTABLISH WATER TEMPERATURE AND OR WATER QUALITY MONITORING AT APPROXIMATELY 40 FIELD SITES IN DIFFERENT PRIORITY WATERSHEDS ACROSS THE STATE ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED  AS PART OF THIS AWARD, ACCS WILL COOPERATE WITH BLM TO ACCOMPLISH TWO OBJECTIVES  1  DEVELOP A STRATEGIC FRAMEWORK FOR SELECTING WATER TEMPERATURE AND WATER QUALITY MONITORING SITES IN HIGH PRIORITY WATERSHEDS WHERE BLM CONDUCTS FRESHWATER MONITORING OR RESTORATION ACTIVITIES AND 2  ESTABLISH NEW MONITORING SITES BY HELPING INSTALL MONITORING EQUIPMENT AT SELECTED LOCATIONS  SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES PROPOSED UNDER THE FIRST OBJECTIVE INCLUDE DEVELOPING AN INVENTORY OF HISTORIC AND CURRENT MONITORING LOCATIONS MANAGED BY BLM OR OTHER ORGANIZATIONS IN EACH STUDY REGION  E G , AREA MANAGED BY A FIELD OFFICE , MEETING WITH BLM BIOLOGISTS AND FIELD STAFF TO DISCUSS MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES AND CRITERIA FOR SITE SELECTION, DEVELOPING AN INTERACTIVE WEB MAPPER FOR SITE SELECTION, AND CONDUCTING OUTREACH TO OTHER AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS TO LEVERAGE RESOURCES AMONG GROUPS AND AVOID DUPLICATION OF EFFORTS  DEPENDING UPON BLM INTEREST AND NEED, TWO ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES PROPOSED UNDER OBJECTIVE 1 INCLUDE CONDUCTING A REVIEW REMOTE SENSING PRODUCTS AND METHODS FOR CHARACTERIZING WATER TEMPERATURES IN REMOTE REGIONS OF ALASKA AND REVIEWING DISCRETE AND DISCONTINUOUS WATER QUALITY MONITORING METHODS SPECIFIC TO PARAMETERS OF INTEREST TO BLM  E G  TURBIDITY IN MINING WATERSHEDS   SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES PROPOSED UNDER THE SECOND OBJECTIVE INCLUDE CONDUCTING FIELD WORK TO DEPLOY WATER TEMPERATURE AND WATER QUALITY LOGGERS IN HIGH PRIORITY WATERSHEDS, CREATING SITE METADATA AND SHARING ALL DEPLOYMENT INFORMATION, AND PROCESSING REMOTE SENSING DATA OR EMPIRICAL DATASETS AS NEEDED

THE VILLAGE OF NUIQSUT IN THE NORTHEAST NATIONAL PETROLEUM RESERVE IN ALASKA  NPR A  IS LARGELY SURROUNDED BY OIL AND GAS  OAND G  EXPLORATION AND DEVELOPMENT, INCLUDING A NUMBER OF ACTIVITIES ON BLM MANAGED LANDS IN THE REGION  LIKE OTHER REMOTE VILLAGES WITHIN THE NORTH SLOPE, COMMUNITY MEMBERS ARE HEAVILY DEPENDENT ON LOCALLY AVAILABLE SUBSISTENCE FOODS SUCH AS CARIBOU, MARINE MAMMALS, AND NON SALMON FISHES  MORE SPECIFICALLY, NON SALMON FISH SPECIES ACCOUNT FOR UP TO 23  OF THE COMMUNITY S TOTAL ESTIMATED HARVEST  DUE TO THE PROXIMITY OF THIS COMMUNITY TO PERMANENT OAND G FACILITIES, THERE HAS BEEN INCREASING CONCERN AMONG NORTH SLOPE COMMUNITIES REGARDING POTENTIAL ACCUMULATION OF CONTAMINANTS SPECIFICALLY POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC HYDROCARBONS  PAHS  IN SUBSISTENCE FISHES  AS SUCH, FUNDING FOR THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL BE USED TO ASSESS LEVELS OF PAHS IN SEDIMENTS OF THE COLVILLE RIVER AND SUBSISTENCE FISHES IMPORTANT TO THE COMMUNITY OF NUIQSUT  BY WORKING COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF NUIQSUT TO ADDRESS CONCERNS REGARDING POTENTIAL WATER POLLUTION AND CONTAMINATION OF SUBSISTENCE FOODS, THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ADDRESS MULTIPLE DOI AND BIDEN HARRIS ADMINISTRATION PRIORITIES INCLUDING,  1  CENTERING EQUALITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE,  2  STRENGTHENING THE GOVERNMENT TO GOVERNMENT RELATIONSHIP WITH SOVEREIGN TRIBAL NATIONS, AND  3  ADVANCING RACIAL EQUALITY AND SUPPORT FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES THROUGH THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT  EXECUTIVE ORDER 13985   THE PAH LEVELS DOCUMENTED DURING THIS MONITORING EFFORT WILL BE COMPARED TO BASELINE VALUES ESTABLISHED IN THE EARLY 2000S TO IDENTIFY SPATIAL AND TEMPORAL TRENDS AND TO HELP INFORM THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE 2020 INTEGRATED ACTIVITY PLAN  IAP  ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STATEMENT  EIS  REQUIRED OPERATING PROCEDURES  ROPS  DESIGNED TO MINIMIZE POTENTIAL CONTAMINANTS ON FISH, WILDLIFE, AND THE ENVIRONMENT  IN ADDITION, THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WOULD SERVE AS A BENCHMARK FROM WHICH TO EVALUATE PAH LEVELS AS PART OF A LONG TERM MONITORING EFFORT TO ENCOURAGE ENVIRONMENTALLY RESPONSIBLE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT IN THE NPR A  THIS MONITORING EFFORT WILL ENSURE AND ENCOURAGE RESPONSIBLE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT IN THE ARCTIC  FINALLY, THIS STUDY WILL TARGET SUBSISTENCE FISH THAT HAVE BEEN FOUND WITH FRESHWATER MOLD TO EXAMINE POTENTIAL ASSOCIATION BETWEEN MOLD PRESENCE AND PAH LEVELS

THE BLM IN WYOMING AND TROUT UNLIMITED HAS A VERY SUCCESSFUL LONG-TERM PARTNERSHIP. THE PROJECTS IN THIS NEW PROPOSAL REFLECT THAT. MUDDY CREEK AND SAVERY CREEK PROJECTS ARE ONGOING AND ARE MULTI-PHASED, THEY BOTH HAVE ALREADY EXPERIENCED EXCELLENT OUTCOMES. THIS FUNDING WILL CONTINUE TO MAKE MUDDY CREEK AND SAVERY CREEK TRUE NATIVE FISH AND HABITAT RESTORATION SUCCESS STORIES.

THIS PROJECT IS ABOUT HELPING THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT  BLM  REIMAGINE THE ROLE ITS  RIVERSCAPES CAN PLAY AS A CORNERSTONE TO INCREASING CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND PROTECTING BIODIVERSITY ON  AMERICA S PUBLIC LANDS  WITH THE CURRENT ADMINISTRATION ROBUSTLY ADDRESSING THE INTERTWINED CLIMATE AND  NATURE CRISES, BLM HAS A RIPE OPPORTUNITY TO DRAMATICALLY INCREASE THE HEALTH OF LANDSCAPES IT IS ENTRUSTED  TO STEWARD BY VIEWING ITS RIVERSCAPES AS A CRITICAL PIECE OF NATURAL INFRASTRUCTURE FUNDAMENTAL TO A  COHERENT CLIMATE ADAPTATION AND RESILIENCE AGENDA  RESTORING DEGRADED STREAM CHANNELS INTO HEALTHY,  FUNCTIONING RIVERSCAPES WILL HELP THESE LANDSCAPES MORE RELIABLY YIELD BENEFITS IN WATER QUANTITY,  WATER QUALITY, HABITAT FOR TERRESTRIAL AND AQUATIC SPECIES, RECREATION, AND CARBON SEQUESTRATION, WHILE  SIMULTANEOUSLY INCREASING RESILIENCE TO THE INCREASING FREQUENCY AND SEVERITY OF DROUGHTS, FLOODS AND  FIRES  TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, WE ARE PROPOSING THIS PROJECT TO SUPPORT BLM IN ESTABLISHING A HEALTHY  RIVERSCAPE INITIATIVE THAT PRIORITIZES INVESTING IN LOW TECH, PROCESS BASED RESTORATION TO IMPROVE THE  CONDITION OF AND EXPAND RIVERSCAPE HABITAT ON BLM MANAGED LANDS  THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON THE I   EDUCATION AND TRAINING, THE II  DEVELOPMENT OF GEOSPATIAL TOOLS AND STANDARDS  I E  DECISION SUPPORT , AND  THE III  SCIENTIFIC STUDIES TO BUILD THE CONFIDENCE AND EXPAND THE CAPACITY OF BLM AND ITS PARTNERS TO  REALIZE THE VISION OF HEALTHIER RIVERSCAPES

THE SIXES RIVER COMPONENT OF THIS PROPOSAL WILL IDENTIFY CRITICAL AREAS ON THE LANDSCAPE TO ADDRESS LIMITING FACTORS TO WATER QUALITY. IDENTIFICATION, PRIORITIZATION, AND STRATEGIC TREATMENT OF PRIORITY SEDIMENT SOURCES ASSOCIATED WITH ROAD NETWORKS ON FORESTRY LANDS WILL REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF SEDIMENT DELIVERED TO THE STREAM NETWORK. THIS WILL LEAD TO A REDUCTION IN TURBIDITY AND TOTAL SUSPENDED SOLIDS (TSS) WITHIN THE WATER COLUMN. LOWER TURBIDITY AND TSS VALUES WILL ALLOW FOR INCREASED PRIMARY PRODUCTIVITY AND MORE ROBUST POPULATIONS OF MACROINVERTEBRATES THAT PROVIDE FORAGE FOR JUVENILE SALMONIDS. CLEARER WATER ALSO INCREASES THE REACTIVE DISTANCE FOR SALMONIDS TO DETECT AND ORIENT THEMSELVES TOWARDS PREY, WHICH CAN INCREASE JUVENILE GROWTH AND SURVIVAL. THE NEED FOR SEDIMENT REDUCTION IN THE SIXES WATERSHED WAS PRIORITIZED THROUGH A MULTI-PARTNER STRATEGIC ACTION PLAN FOR THE SIXES RIVER WATERSHED COMPLETED IN 2019, AND ROAD SYSTEMS WITHIN SUBWATERSHEDS WERE FURTHER PRIORITIZED WITH BLM AND OTHER PARTNERS IN 2021.

THE PROJECT ACTIVITY WILL INCLUDE THE SIMULTANEOUS MONITORING AND SURVEY OF CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROGS AND AMERICAN BULLFROGS, AT BOTH KNOWN OCCUPIED LOCATIONS AND POTENTIALLY OCCUPIED LOCATIONS. IN THE CASE THAT BULLFROGS ARE DISCOVERED, SURVEYORS WILL REMOVE THEM FROM ANY LOCATION THEY ARE FOUND. THIS WORK FOLLOWS PREVIOUS SUCCESSFUL EFFORTS TO REDUCE BULLFROG POPULATIONS IN THE REGION. MONITORING REFERS TO VISITING SITES THAT ARE KNOWN TO BE OCCUPIED; SURVEYING REFERS TO VISITING SITES THAT HAVE POTENTIAL TO BE OCCUPIED BUT HAVE NOT BEEN YET VERIFIED TO HAVE EITHER SPECIES OF FROG. THE PROJECT IS IN ACCORDANCE WITH CONSERVATION MEASURES PROVIDED IN BIOLOGICAL OPINION 02-21-02-F-162. THE PROJECT IS WITHIN THE CIENEGA CREEK WATERSHED AND BENEFITS FISH AND WILDLIFE WITHIN THE LAS CIENEGAS NATIONAL CONSERVATION AREA (LCNCA). BULLFROGS ARE CONSIDERED A MAJOR THREAT TO CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROGS BY PREDATION AND COMPETITION.

THE CHEMEHUEVI INDIAN TRIBE WILL ESTABLISH A PUBLIC EDUCATION PROGRAM THAT ADDRESSES CONTAINMENT OF QUAGGA MUSSELS CONSISTENT WITH THE WESTERN REGIONAL PANEL, QUAGGA AND ZEBRA ACTION PLAN AND INTERIOR'S SAFEGUARDING THE WEST STRATEGY. THERE IS CURRENTLY NO FORMAL QUAGGA MUSSEL PROGRAM ON THE RESERVATION ADDRESSING WATERCRAFT INSPECTION, DECONTAMINATION, AND CONTAINMENT EFFORTS ON THE LOWER COLORADO RIVER, ESPECIALLY IN CALIFORNIA.

THE ARIZONA GAME AND FISH DEPARTMENT (AZGFD) WILL USE FUNDING TO SUPPORT WATERCRAFT INSPECTION AND DECONTAMINATIONS FOR HIGH RISK BOATERS ON LAKE HAVASU AND THE PARKER STRIP, WITH A FOCUS ON BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM) FACILITIES AND COOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT AREAS. FUNDING WILL ALSO SUPPORT EFFORTS TO UNDERSTAND THE EFFECTS OF QUAGGA MUSSELS ON ARTIFICIAL FISH HABITAT AND CURRENT HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS.
